message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and positive HLA-B27 test suggest that he has juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) with associated uveitis. Iridocyclitis, or uveitis, is a common complication of JIA, affecting up to 25% of patients. Sacroiliitis and scoliosis are also possible complications, but not as common as uveitis. Aortitis is more commonly associated with ankylosing spondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and positive HLA-B27 are suggestive of Juvenile idiopathic arthritis, which is associated with increased risk of developing iridocyclitis. Sacroiliitis and spondyloarthropathy are also common, but the question specifically asks for the most likely risk. Scoliosis is not directly associated with this condition. Aortitis, while a possible complication of ankylosing spondylitis, is not mentioned in the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (sJIA) which is associated with uveitis or iridocyclitis. There is no mention of symptoms related to sacroiliitis, scoliosis or aortitis. The positive HLA-B27 indicates an increased risk of developing enthesitis-related arthritis (ERA) and axial spondyloarthropathy (AS).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms consistent with systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, given the waxing and waning fever, joint swelling, and positive HLA-B27. Iridocyclitis, inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, is a common complication of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, while sacroiliitis, scoliosis, and aortitis are less common. Therefore, the most likely answer is (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of symmetric joint swelling in the knees and wrists, a salmon-colored truncal rash, and a positive HLA-B27 points towards a diagnosis of juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Patients with HLA-B27 positive juvenile idiopathic arthritis are at increased risk of developing iridocyclitis, an inflammation in the eye. While sacroiliitis and aortitis are also possible complications of HLA-B27 positive arthritis, they are less likely in a 4-year-old patient. Scoliosis is not typically associated with HLA-B27 positive arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age, joint symptoms, and positive HLA-B27 suggest a diagnosis of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, specifically the subtype of oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis. This subtype is associated with an increased risk of developing iridocyclitis/uveitis, which can lead to vision loss if not treated promptly. Sacroiliitis is more commonly associated with the enthesitis-related subtype of juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Scoliosis and aortitis are less commonly associated with any subtype of juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and positive HLA-B27 test suggest the most likely diagnosis is juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Among the complications of this type of arthritis, iridocyclitis is the most common, occurring in about 20% to 30% of patients. Sacroiliitis is also a common complication, but less likely to cause visual impairment. Scoliosis and aortitis are less common complications of juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of symmetric joint swelling in the child’s knees and wrists that has become increasingly noticeable over the past 8 weeks, a macular, salmon-colored truncal rash, and a positive HLA-B27 all point to the diagnosis of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, most specifically the subtype of oligoarticular arthritis. Oligoarticular arthritis is associated with uveitis/iridocyclitis, particularly in those who are ANA negative and HLA-B27 positive. None of the other answer options are commonly associated with oligoarticular arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and serology suggest juvenile idiopathic arthritis, which puts the patient at increased risk of developing iridocyclitis. While sacroiliitis and scoliosis may also occur in patients with JIA, they are not the most likely complication based on this presentation. Aortitis is not a known complication of JIA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, symmetric joint swelling in knees and wrists, and positive human leukocyte antigen B27 suggest a high likelihood of developing iridocyclitis, an inflammation of the iris and ciliary body that can lead to blindness. Other options such as sacroiliitis, scoliosis, and aortitis are also associated with human leukocyte antigen B27 positivity, but do not have a direct association with the patient’s symptoms.
